question: Question_02
statement:
Consider the following two statements:

\[\mathbf{(a)} \text{ for all } w \in \mathbb{R}, \text{ there exists } x \in \mathbb{R} \text{ such that } w < x.\]

\[\mathbf{(b)} \text{ there exists } y \in \mathbb{R} \text{ such that for all } z \in \mathbb{R} \text{, } y < z.\]
One of the statement is true, and the other is false. Determine which is
which. For the true one, prove that it is true; for the false one, prove
that it is false.
sols:
The second statement should appear wrong fairly immediately since it
talking about the existence of \emph{the smallest real number} which
cannot exist. Let's prove this:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
The statement says that for \emph{any} real number \emph{z} it should be
true that \emph{y} \textless{} \emph{z}, but if I pick \emph{z} to be
exactly that mysterious number \emph{y} I should have \emph{y}
\textless{} \emph{y} which is clearly impossible, so the statement is
false.
\end{description}

Now we can prove that the first statement is true:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
That statement says that if any real number \emph{w} is picked, then one
can find a real number \emph{x} that is larger than \emph{w}. Well, sure
enough, if one always choses \emph{x} = \emph{w} + 1, then clearly it is
always going to be larger than the \emph{w} that was picked in the first
place.
\end{description}
hints: Try reformulating these two statements into more readable English.
